subject: 🎟️The Exchange 2025: Tickets Still Available!
body:
The Exchange 2025 presented by Southwest Airlines

The Exchange 2025: Next Week – Secure Your Spot!
 
Time is running out! 
The Exchange 2025 is happening NEXT WEEK
 on 
April 10 at Soldier Field
—and tickets are still available! Don’t miss your chance to be part of the Chicagoland Chamber’s
 largest networking event of the year
, presented by 
Southwest Airlines.
 
Here are four reasons why you won’t want to miss out:
 
1. Unmatched Networking Potential
With over 100 exhibitors and hundreds of attendees, this is the place to be if you’re looking to make meaningful connections. Our 
Speed Networking by LinkedIn
 sessions will help you quickly meet potential clients, partners, and industry leaders, ensuring you get the most out of your time at the event.
 
2. Learn from Industry Experts
Take part in 
Chamber Chats
—interactive, 20-minute sessions led by top experts. This year’s topics cover pressing issues like talent trends and affordable small business health insurance, designed to help you stay ahead in today’s fast-moving business world.
 
3. Savor Chicago’s Best Flavors
Indulge in the 
Culinary Showcase by Grubhub
, where you can sample delicious bites from Chicago’s top restaurants. Whether you’re a foodie or just love great cuisine, this is the perfect chance to enjoy local favorites and sip on complimentary beverages as you network.
 
4. Experience Soldier Field
The Exchange 2025 isn’t just about business—it’s about experiencing the legendary Soldier Field. Explore exclusive club spaces and take in the rich history and atmosphere of this iconic venue while you connect and learn!
 
Special Offer: Buy 3 Tickets, Get 1 Free!
For a limited time, when you buy three tickets, you’ll receive a fourth one at no extra cost! It’s the perfect opportunity to bring along your colleagues or business partners. Don’t wait!
The Exchange 2025 is one event you won’t want to miss. Reserve your tickets today, and get ready to 
connect, learn, and grow
 at Soldier Field on April 10!

subject: The Future Belongs to Bold Leaders. Are You In?
body:
One month left! Don’t miss the award-winning Justice for All Summit: The Power of Inclusion, April 21-24.
 
Your Moment to Lead Is Here.
 
The path forward isn’t always clear, but 
bold leaders don’t wait for certainty. They take action.
 
Join us for the third-annual 
Justice for All Summit: The Power of Inclusion
,
 April 21-24. We are bringing together visionaries and thought leaders for dynamic conversations, 60+ transformative sessions, six powerhouse keynote speakers like Ben Cohen and Adam Grant, and unparalleled networking opportunities.
 
With 
less than ONE MONTH to go
, now is the time to secure your spot. 
Register for the 2025 Justice for All Summit
 
We’ll be covering it all — tech and AI, inclusive leadership, the legal landscape of DEI, accessibility practices, ERGs, and much more. 
(
You can preview all the sessions before registering here.
)
 Don’t miss your chance to gain the insights, connections, and strategies you need to lead with confidence in today’s shifting landscape.
 
PS to make the Summit more accessible, we introduced a 
Pay What You Can model
 for registration.
 
 
The 2024 Racial Justice at Work Summit: Justice for All won the Gold Stevie® Award for Event of the Year!
More than 1,500 entries from organizations and individuals in 36 nations and territories were submitted this year for consideration in more than 100 categories. We are proud to be recognized and can't wait to continue the momentum April 21-24, 2025.
 
We need to stand united in our support of diversity, equity, and inclusion — and each other. The transformation starts here with your commitment and support.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The Winters Group, 8116 South Tryon Street, Ste. B3-260, Charlotte, North Carolina 28273, United States

subject: RE: IDI
body:
Hi Larry,
Hope your day is going well.  Thanks for sending this to me.  I am updating the deck.  Check out V3.  I will send a Dropbox link.
 
This looks really good.  Just the Minimization example is solid for minimization, but does not really showcase a generational lens difference.  We can discuss it tomorrow.
 
Cheers~
 
Andrea Wicks Bowles

From:
 Larry Baker <l.baker@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, April 2, 2025 10:49 AM
To:
 Andrea Wicks Bowles <a.wicksbowles@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Larry Baker <lbjbaker1@gmail.com>
Subject:
 FW: IDI
 
 
Tell me what you think about these for the IDI slide.
Intercultural Development Inventory Stages in Workplace Generational Interactions
Here are examples of how the five IDI stages might manifest when dealing with different generations in the workplace:
1. Denial
Example scenario:
 A Baby Boomer manager dismisses the work-life balance concerns of Millennial employees as simply "not having a strong work ethic."
What's happening:
 The manager fails to recognize the legitimate cultural differences in how generations view work, instead attributing differences to character flaws. They might say, "When I was their age, we just worked hard without complaining. These kids today just want everything handed to them."
2. Polarization
Example scenario:
 Gen Z employees form an informal coalition and openly criticize older colleagues for being "out of touch" with technology and social trends.
What's happening:
 The younger employees have created an "us vs. them" dynamic, judging the older workers negatively based on generational stereotypes. They might express frustration like, "The Boomers are holding us back with their outdated ideas—they need to retire already" (Defense), or conversely, "The older generation's approach to in-person relationship building is so much more authentic than our digital connections" (Reversal).
3. Minimization
Example scenario:
 
A Gen X team leader says, "Age doesn't matter in our workplace—we're all just professionals trying to do our jobs well."
What's happening:
 While seemingly inclusive, this perspective masks important generational differences in communication styles, work preferences, and values. The team leader is emphasizing universal qualities ("we're all professionals") while unintentionally invalidating the unique perspectives and challenges each generation brings to the workplace.
4. Acceptance
Example scenario:
 A Millennial project manager acknowledges that different generations have distinct approaches to collaboration and deliberately creates mixed-generation teams to capitalize on diverse perspectives.
What's happening:
 The manager recognizes that Baby Boomers might prefer scheduled meetings and formal documentation, Gen X values independence and efficiency, and Gen Z excels with digital collaboration tools. Rather than judging these differences, the manager respects them as valid cultural variations and designs team processes that accommodate different styles.
5. Adaptation
Example scenario:
 A leadership team composed of multiple generations develops a flexible workplace policy that incorporates elements appealing to all age groups.
What's happening:
 The policy includes structured career paths (appealing to Boomers), autonomous work arrangements (valued by Gen X), purpose-driven projects (important to Millennials), and tech-enabled collaboration with rapid feedback (preferred by Gen Z). Leaders shift their communication styles based on their audience—using more formal channels with older employees and more digital platforms with younger staff—while helping different generations translate for each other.
In the Adaptation stage, there might be a mentoring program where older employees share institutional knowledge and younger employees provide reverse mentoring on digital skills, creating a genuinely collaborative multigenerational workplace where differences are leveraged as strengths rather than seen as obstacles.

subject: FW: IDI
body:
Tell me what you think about these for the IDI slide.
Intercultural Development Inventory Stages in Workplace Generational Interactions
Here are examples of how the five IDI stages might manifest when dealing with different generations in the workplace:
1. Denial
Example scenario:
 A Baby Boomer manager dismisses the work-life balance concerns of Millennial employees as simply "not having a strong work ethic."
What's happening:
 The manager fails to recognize the legitimate cultural differences in how generations view work, instead attributing differences to character flaws. They might say, "When I was their age, we just worked hard without complaining. These kids today just want everything handed to them."
2. Polarization
Example scenario:
 Gen Z employees form an informal coalition and openly criticize older colleagues for being "out of touch" with technology and social trends.
What's happening:
 The younger employees have created an "us vs. them" dynamic, judging the older workers negatively based on generational stereotypes. They might express frustration like, "The Boomers are holding us back with their outdated ideas—they need to retire already" (Defense), or conversely, "The older generation's approach to in-person relationship building is so much more authentic than our digital connections" (Reversal).
3. Minimization
Example scenario:
 
A Gen X team leader says, "Age doesn't matter in our workplace—we're all just professionals trying to do our jobs well."
What's happening:
 While seemingly inclusive, this perspective masks important generational differences in communication styles, work preferences, and values. The team leader is emphasizing universal qualities ("we're all professionals") while unintentionally invalidating the unique perspectives and challenges each generation brings to the workplace.
4. Acceptance
Example scenario:
 A Millennial project manager acknowledges that different generations have distinct approaches to collaboration and deliberately creates mixed-generation teams to capitalize on diverse perspectives.
What's happening:
 The manager recognizes that Baby Boomers might prefer scheduled meetings and formal documentation, Gen X values independence and efficiency, and Gen Z excels with digital collaboration tools. Rather than judging these differences, the manager respects them as valid cultural variations and designs team processes that accommodate different styles.
5. Adaptation
Example scenario:
 A leadership team composed of multiple generations develops a flexible workplace policy that incorporates elements appealing to all age groups.
What's happening:
 The policy includes structured career paths (appealing to Boomers), autonomous work arrangements (valued by Gen X), purpose-driven projects (important to Millennials), and tech-enabled collaboration with rapid feedback (preferred by Gen Z). Leaders shift their communication styles based on their audience—using more formal channels with older employees and more digital platforms with younger staff—while helping different generations translate for each other.
In the Adaptation stage, there might be a mentoring program where older employees share institutional knowledge and younger employees provide reverse mentoring on digital skills, creating a genuinely collaborative multigenerational workplace where differences are leveraged as strengths rather than seen as obstacles.

 Larry Baker <

Subject:
 Examples for Ultieg
 
Cross-Generational Developmental Conversations
Scenario 1: Boomer Manager & Gen Z Employee
Context:
 Marketing department of a retail company 
Topic:
 Communication style and formality 
Characters:
 Patricia (59, Baby Boomer, Marketing Director) and Tyler (23, Gen Z, Marketing Coordinator)
Conversation:
Patricia:
 Tyler, I wanted to chat about your communication style in client meetings. I've noticed you tend to use casual language and abbreviations that some of our more traditional clients might not understand.
Tyler:
 Yeah, I get that. I guess I'm just communicating how I normally would. Is it really that big of a deal?
Patricia:
 In some contexts, it can be. Many of our established clients expect a certain level of formality. It signals professionalism to them.
Tyler:
 That's interesting. I actually find that being authentic and speaking naturally helps me build better connections. My generation values authenticity over formality.
Patricia:
 I appreciate that perspective. Perhaps we can find a middle ground. Could you consider adjusting your style for certain clients while maintaining your authentic approach with others?
Tyler:
 I could definitely be more mindful of my audience. Maybe you could help me identify which clients might prefer more formal communication?
Patricia:
 That's a great solution. I'll share my insights about our client preferences, and perhaps you could teach me some of the more effective casual communication techniques that work well with younger clients.
Tyler:
 I'd be happy to! I think we could both learn from each other's strengths here.
Scenario 2: Millennial Manager & Boomer Employee
Context:
 Financial services firm 
Topic:
 Adapting to technological changes 
Characters:
 Jessica (38, Millennial, Team Lead) and Robert (62, Baby Boomer, Financial Analyst)
Conversation:
Jessica:
 Robert, I've noticed you're still using the old spreadsheet method for client data analysis rather than the new CRM system we implemented last month.
Robert:
 The spreadsheet system has worked perfectly fine for the past 15 years. I can get the same results without having to learn an entirely new system.
Jessica:
 I understand you've developed efficient systems over your career. However, the new CRM offers features that significantly speed up analysis and allows for better team collaboration.
Robert:
 I've built my career on accuracy and thoroughness. I'm concerned that rushing to adopt new technology might compromise that quality.
Jessica:
 I deeply respect your commitment to quality. What if we approach this as an opportunity to combine your analytical expertise with new tools that can enhance what you already do well?
Robert:
 I suppose I've been resisting because I'm worried about the learning curve. At this stage in my career, starting from scratch feels challenging.
Jessica:
 That's a valid concern. What if I arranged for one-on-one training sessions? Your experience is incredibly valuable to our team, and combining that with new technological capabilities would be powerful.
Robert:
 I appreciate you recognizing that. I'm willing to give it a try with proper support. Perhaps I could also document some of the analytical approaches I've developed that might be integrated into the new system.
Jessica:
 That would be excellent! Your expertise could help us customize the CRM to better serve our specific needs.
Scenario 3: Gen X Colleagues of Different Racial Backgrounds
Context:
 University administration 
Topic:
 Inclusive leadership and cultural awareness 
Characters:
 Marcus (48, Black, Associate Dean) and Diane (45, White, Department Chair)
Conversation:
Marcus:
 Diane, I wanted to discuss something I observed in yesterday's faculty meeting. When Professor Johnson, who is Korean American, was speaking about her research, she was interrupted several times.
Diane:
 I noticed that too, but I wasn't sure if I should step in. I sometimes worry about overstepping or making assumptions about what others might need.
Marcus:
 I understand that concern. As leaders in our department, though, I think we need to be more proactive about ensuring everyone's voice is heard equally.
Diane:
 You're right. I realize I may have hesitated because I'm sometimes unsure about how to address these moments without making them more awkward. How do you approach these situations?
Marcus:
 For me, it's about establishing clear meeting norms from the beginning. I've found that simple statements like "Let's make sure we hear everyone's complete thoughts before responding" can make a difference.
Diane:
 That's helpful. I think I also need to become more comfortable with the discomfort that can come with addressing these moments directly.
Marcus:
 Absolutely. And from my experience as a Black man in academia, I can tell you that the discomfort of having someone interrupt these patterns is far less than the discomfort of being repeatedly interrupted or overlooked.
Diane:
 That's an important perspective I hadn't fully considered. I'd appreciate your feedback as I work on being more proactive. Maybe we could collaborate on developing some departmental guidelines for inclusive discussions?
Marcus:
 I'd be happy to work on that together. By combining our different perspectives and experiences, we could create something that really addresses the needs of our diverse faculty.
Scenario 4: Gen Z Manager & Millennial Employee
Context:
 Tech startup 
Topic:
 Work-life boundaries and productivity 
Characters:
 Zoe (27, Gen Z, Product Manager) and Miguel (35, Millennial, Software Developer)
Conversation:
Zoe:
 Miguel, I noticed you've been responding to Slack messages at midnight and sending emails on weekends. I'm concerned about potential burnout.
Miguel:
 I appreciate your concern, but I'm just trying to stay on top of everything. This project is important, and I want to make sure we meet our deadlines.
Zoe:
 I understand the commitment to the project, but our company values sustainable productivity. We don't expect people to be available 24/7.
Miguel:
 In my previous companies, responsiveness was highly valued. It showed dedication to the job.
Zoe:
 That's interesting. For my generation, we've seen the negative effects of always-on culture. Research shows that proper rest actually improves overall productivity and creativity.
Miguel:
 I guess I'm still carrying expectations from previous workplace cultures. Sometimes I worry that if I'm not constantly available, it might seem like I'm not committed enough.
Zoe:
 Your commitment is evident in the quality of your work, not in when you respond to messages. What if we establish some team agreements about communication hours?
Miguel:
 That could help set clearer expectations. To be honest, it would be nice to disconnect more without feeling guilty.
Zoe:
 Exactly. Let's work together to define what healthy boundaries look like for our team. Your experience is valuable, and I want to make sure you're set up for long-term success here, not just short-term output.
Miguel:
 I appreciate that. It's actually refreshing to have a manager who prioritizes wellbeing alongside performance.
Scenario 5: Gen X Manager & Gen Alpha Intern
Context:
 Environmental nonprofit 
Topic:
 Professional communication and expectations 
Characters:
 Lisa (44, Gen X, Program Director) and Aiden (16, Gen Alpha, Summer Intern)
Conversation:
Lisa:
 Aiden, I wanted to check in about your first few weeks with us. How are you finding the experience?
Aiden:
 It's been cool! I really like the mission. But sometimes I'm not sure what I'm supposed to be doing or if I'm doing things right.
Lisa:
 Thanks for sharing that. Could you tell me more about where you're feeling uncertain?
Aiden:
 Well, like yesterday when you asked me to "circle back" with the volunteers, I wasn't really sure what that meant. And sometimes I feel like I should be doing more, but I don't want to mess anything up.
Lisa:
 I see. I should be more clear with my instructions and avoid jargon. "Circling back" just means following up with them about their availability.
Aiden:
 That makes sense. Also, is it okay to message you with questions? I use messaging apps for everything, but I'm not sure what's professional.
Lisa:
 Great question. For quick clarifications, messaging is perfect. For more complex discussions or anything involving program decisions, I'd prefer we talk in person or schedule a video call.
Aiden:
 Got it. That helps a lot.
Lisa:
 I'm curious - what methods of communication do you find most effective?
Aiden:
 I like how we use different channels for different types of communication here. But maybe having some examples of professional messages would help me understand the expectations better.
Lisa:
 That's an excellent suggestion. I can put together some templates and examples. And Aiden, please know that asking questions is exactly what you should be doing as an intern. It shows engagement and a desire to learn.
Aiden:
 Thanks! I'm really excited to learn how things work in a professional environment. It's pretty different from school.
Lisa:
 That's why internships are so valuable. And I appreciate your digital fluency – it brings a fresh perspective to our team. Let's set up a quick check-in meeting each week to address any questions and make sure you're getting the most out of this experience.

subject: Staying committed when our work is in trouble
body:
📅 
Happenings
APRIL FREE WEBINAR
 -
 
Join us for a free open webinar with special guests. 
90 Days In: Reigniting Actionable Allyship in a Defining Moment 
takes place on 
Apr. 23rd at 1pm ET.
 Join Julie Kratz, Dr. Akilah Cadet, and Karen Catlin for a conversation tackling tough but necessary conversations on allyship, action, and accountability. Learn how to move beyond performative gestures, re-engage meaningfully, and navigate discomfort in today’s political and social climate. Whether you’re setting boundaries, or taking your activism further, this session is for you. 
Register for free here
.
April Webinar Details
INTERNATIONAL ALLYSHIP DAY
 - Join us in NYC or virtually on August 8th for our 
2nd annual International Allyship Day event
, hosted by our partner AllianceBernstein. This year’s focus is on equipping inclusion and ERG leaders with actionable strategies to strengthen or launch allyship programs within their organizations. Participants will gain essential skills for effective allyship, pushback-proof strategies, and insights into the strategic business impact of allyship. They’ll also have the chance to connect with senior leaders in the inclusion space. We're consistently adding exciting new speakers and organizations like Coqual and Dr. Sandra Upton - 
will your organization be there?
 
Register individually or as a team here
.
​
 
​
📝 Staying committed when our work is in trouble
The current societal climate presents unique challenges for diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) work. While it's easy to fall into binary perspectives, the reality is that our efforts exist within a complex and evolving environment.
Recent developments, including executive orders, have introduced potential legal and funding implications for DEI initiatives, particularly for government-affiliated organizations. However, it's important to acknowledge that a significant majority of leaders remain committed to advancing inclusion, albeit with increased strategic consideration.
To ensure the continued effectiveness and legal defensibility of our DEI programs, we are focusing on:
Legal Compliance:
 Rigorously auditing our initiatives using established frameworks to mitigate potential legal risks.
Risk Analysis:
 Evaluating the potential consequences of pausing DEI efforts, including impacts on employee engagement, innovation, and legal standing.
Internal Communication:
 Reaffirming our commitment to DEI as a core business imperative and cultural value within our organization.
​
Read more in my Forbes article here
.
 
Thanks allies,
Julie
​
💬 
Allyship Conversation Starters & Resources
​
How to Build Career Resilience in Uncertain Times
​
​
​
​
 
​
Beyond DEI: Understanding Public Opinion on Diversity, Equity, & Inclusion

​

LITTLE ALLIES
, a nonprofit working to facilitate inclusive experiences for all children to feel seen, heard, and belong.

works to promote allyship and inclusion across all dimensions of diversity in the workplace to make sure everyone feels seen, heard, and belonging at work.

subject: Tips for first-time leaders
body:
Plus: why small firms pass up valuable opportunities. 
April 2, 2025  ·  
View in browser
 
The Insightful Leader
BY 
KELLOGG INSIGHT
Leadership advice from the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University
Good morning,
The transition from individual contributor to first-time manager is a notoriously bumpy ride that requires you to use a muscle you (probably) weren’t trained to flex: helping others grow.
This week, 
Harry Kraemer
, a clinical professor of management and organizations at Kellogg and former chairman and CEO of Baxter International, shares tips to help fledgling leaders stick the landing. 
Plus, what makes small businesses hesitant to take advantage of simple opportunities to improve their bottom line? 
A more-successful transition into management
In his 40 years in business, Kraemer’s seen new leaders fall into some of the same traps: they micromanage instead of delegating because they’re more comfortable doing everything themselves, for example. And they’re often so focused on being seen as “irreplaceable” that they end up overshadowing their teams. Unfortunately, Kraemer writes, someone who is irreplaceable in a role is not likely to be promoted out of it.
Kraemer writes that the struggles of first-time managers should be a wake-up call for more-experienced leaders to step up and support them. He offers several tips to that end.
 
First, be a values-based leader, which means constantly reflecting on what matters most so that you can have a positive impact on others. Kraemer’s approach to values-based leadership is anchored in four principles: self-reflection, a balanced perspective, true self-confidence, and genuine humility. 
Self-reflection is particularly important because it can help you better understand your own priorities and what matters most to you. 
“If you are not self-reflective, how can you know yourself; and if you do not know yourself, how can you lead yourself? And if you cannot lead yourself, how can you possibly lead others?” Kraemer writes.
Another tip for aspiring leaders is to understand that you don’t—and can’t—know everything. Gathering input can provide you with a more balanced perspective and help you correct for blindspots. 
“This applies to gathering input from others on the best way to tackle a project, as well as to engage with people who hold different and contradictory views, especially in today’s 
polarized world
,” Kramer writes. 
Read more from Kraemer in 
Forbes
.
Why small firms pass up valuable opportunities
Sean Higgins
's recent research grew out of a surprising observation: small businesses don’t always take advantage of simple opportunities to improve their bottom line.
Higgins, a Kellogg associate professor of finance, was consulting with a Mexico-based fintech company that charged merchants a fee for credit-card-payment processing. When a competitor had begun offering a lower fee, the fintech company wanted to test lowering its own fee as well. 
“The idea was to shift some customers to card payments by making those payments cheap enough to offset the indirect costs of using cash, like having to handle it and go to the bank frequently,” Higgins says.
But when he helped the company run a pilot study that offered the lower fee to about 11,000 merchants, only about 15 percent opted in. 
The result motivated Higgins and collaborators Paul Gertler and Ulrike Malmendier of UC Berkeley and Waldo Ojeda of Columbia to study why small businesses hesitate to act. They designed an experiment to test whether behavioral frictions (such as forgetfulness or failing to think long term) could explain why businesses were resistant to taking certain actions that might benefit them. 
They found that several tools significantly increased customers’ likelihood of accepting the offer. Above all, “pre-announced reminders had the largest impact,” Higgins says.
“It has something to do with the fintech company telling merchants on day one that the company is going to do something,” he says, “and then following through and actually doing it.”
Read more about the research in 
Kellogg Insight
.
“Since many banking services can be provided online, this will be disproportionately costly to those that have a harder time accessing or using online banking, relative to physical locations, such as the elderly or low-income households.”
— 
Carola Frydman
, in 
Newsweek
, on what the projected closure of hundreds of U.S. bank branches this year means for Americans.
See you next week,
Laura Pavin, multimedia editor
Kellogg Insight
Follow us on 
LinkedIn
.
And listen to our 
podcasts
.

subject: How to blend meritocracy and DEI
body:
April 1st foolery; new EEOC guidance; the impact on veterans; Morgan Stanley DEI backfires  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
View in browser
 
 April 01, 2025
In a shocking reversal, the White House today announced that it is restarting DEI initiatives across all government agencies, restoring funding to all universities, and offering tax breaks to any corporation that shows tangible progress on DEI. 
April Fools'!
 … unfortunately 😭 
 
All jokes aside, we are excited to introduce the 
MIME
 framework, which aligns the calls for meritocracy with key DEI objectives—see below.
 
– Team Aleria 
DEI Backlash: 
Pros
 and 
Cons
Stories focused on the anti-DEI backlash, and efforts to put a stop to the nonsense!
 
Quantifying DEI
Exploring the tangible aspects of DEI and current efforts to quantify it
 
DEI Resources
Useful tools and information to support your DEI efforts
 
The Complexity of DEI
Unintended consequences and ripple effects of DEI
 
Golden Nuggets,
 Silver Linings
Unexpected bits of good news... when we can find them.
We almost never share links to podcasts, but this episode of 
The Future of Work
 is awesome: Jill Finlayson speaks with Bo Young Lee, who brings a wealth of experience to discuss some of the hottest topics about the DEI backlash. On the academic front, 
Harvard will offer free tuition
 to families making less than $200K/year—joining a few other elite schools in diversity push. And our unique work keeps attracting attention: check out the 
latest podcast
 and some quotes in 
CSO magazine
.
 
 
Aleria Happenings
The latest from the Aleria Team
 
Introducing 
MIME
: the Measurable approach to Meritocracy for 
ALL
 Employees
Organizations are searching for ways to comply with the administration's executive orders and the call to “restore meritocracy." But how do you create a truly merit-based system that benefits
 all
 employees? Aleria's 
Measuring Inclusion and Merit for Efficiency
 (
MIME
) 
framework provides the answer.
 
Anchored in the 
MIME
 framework, our 
Inclusive Leadership
 and 
Inclusive Management Training
 
programs give your teams the knowledge, data, tools, and best practices to foster a high-performing, stable workforce—without guesswork, backlash, or legal exposure. 
Our training is fully customizable, from half-day sessions to multi-day deep dives, both in-person and virtually. 
With 
MIME
, you don't just talk about meritocracy—you implement it effectively in a way that benefits 
all
 employees!
 
 
Visit our website
 for additional information, 
send us an email
 to learn more, or use the button below to schedule a call with Aleria's Founder and Chief Scientist, Paolo Gaudiano, who can provide 
more details and answer any questions about how 
Measuring Inclusion and Merit for Efficiency
 can give your organization a competitive advantage.
Book a call with Paolo
 
Mark Your Calendars
DEI-related events, applications and opportunities. Submit relevant events to 
info@aleria.tech
On April 3, 2025 at 12pm US/ET, join Charter and Understood for 
Neurodiversity and the Future of Business
, a discussion of the workplace designs, team dynamics, and leadership approaches to maximize the strengths of neurodivergent workers. The presentation includes case studies and resources that you can use in your own organization. 
Free registration
.
On April 3-9, 2025, join the 17th 
Annual ReelAbilities Film Festival: New York
. This amazing festival, which spans multiple venues and virtual showings, reframes disability and celebrates inclusion and accessibility through film. 
Get your tickets today
!
On April 9, 2025 at 12pm US/ET, join a Fairgodboss webinar on 
Allyship and Self-Advocacy for Career Growth
, featuring leaders from Cargill, who will discuss self-advocacy and allyship. Gain practical strategies to communicate effectively, boost confidence, challenge workplace biases, and foster an inclusive environment for career growth and support. 
Free registration
.
On April 10 at 11:00 am US/ET join our Chief Scientist Paolo Gaudiano for a FREE webinar on 
Rethinking DEI: Addressing Common Misconceptions. 
Paolo we'll dive into the misconceptions surrounding diversity and inclusion, address concerns about meritocracy, and explore practical ways to approach DEI while staying compliant with current policies. 
Free Registration
.
On April 21-24, 2025, The Winters Group will host 
The Power of Inclusion Summit
, a virtual conference designed to support the community during these challenging. There is a Pay What You Can option that lets you pay between $100 and $798 for the April 22-24 sessions. 
Learn more and register.

subject: Declined: [UNSTAFFED] Building an Inclusive GroupM Culture
Declined: [UNSTAFFED] Building an Inclusive GroupM Culture
Pay What You Can & Experience The Power of Inclusion Summit
body:
Flexible registration options are available! Take advantage of group discounts, pay what you can, or apply for financial support
 
Inclusion in Action: A Summit for All
 
The legal threats and funding cuts against DEI have had a significant impact on many organizations and communities. At The Winters Group, we believe that diversity, equity, and inclusion are positive forces in the world that help people thrive. We also believe in the power of 
community
. 
Join us - any way you can
Instead of raising our fees as originally planned, to make the 
Justice for All: The Power of Inclusion Summit
 more accessible we have introduced a 
Pay What You Can
 registration model, where in addition to a $100 fee, you can choose to pay an amount that is affordable for you at this time.
 
If this option is still a hardship, we welcome you to utilize our 
scholarship program
. For those who have already registered, we invite you to bring another member of your organization, or personal acquaintance, at no additional cost. (Details will be forthcoming.)  
If you can pay the full registration fee, we ask you to do so
. We deeply appreciate the support this community has always shown. Producing the Summit was a significant investment, and we believe its impact is needed now more than ever. Your attendance and sponsorships help ensure we can continue this work and build a more inclusive world.
The 
2025 Justice for All Summit: The Power of Inclusion
 is designed to be a transformative experience to help equip you with the tools and insights needed to champion inclusion and equity in our new reality. Together with prominent thought leaders in the fields of diversity, equity, inclusion, accessibility, and justice, we will collectively develop the skills needed to create spaces where differences are not only recognized but also celebrated as strengths.
In moments like these our collective strength has the power to fight back against policies and practices that dehumanize and “other” people. Through the power of inclusion and community, we will stand together and advocate for a more just and inclusive future. We invite you to join with us.
Secure your spot today — your way
 
 
 
The 2024 Racial Justice at Work Summit: Justice for All won the Gold Stevie® Award for Event of the Year!
More than 1,500 entries from organizations and individuals in 36 nations and territories were submitted this year for consideration in more than 100 categories. We are proud to be recognized and can't wait to continue the momentum April 21-24, 2025.
 
We need to stand united in our support of diversity, equity, and inclusion — and each other. The transformation starts here with your commitment and support.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The Winters Group, 8116 South Tryon Street, Ste. B3-260, Charlotte, North Carolina 28273, United States

subject: Red States Reject Data, Force Office Mandates (Wise Decision Maker Guide 149)
body:
Wise Decision Maker Guide 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
Greetings Larry,
Why are some states forcing government employees back to the office despite overwhelming evidence that remote work boosts productivity and saves money?
 Republican-led states like Nebraska, Ohio, Oklahoma, and Wisconsin are pushing rigid return-to-office mandates driven more by political theater than data. Ignoring federal and academic research showing the success of hybrid and remote models, these policies risk damaging public service efficiency and triggering costly turnover—just as seen under Biden’s more moderate RTO approach.
To learn more, check out this 
blog
.
Read Blog
 
Prefer video to text? See this 
video
 based on the blog:
If you prefer audio, listen to this 
podcast
 based on the blog:
Make Your Voice Heard
Vote in this 
LinkedIn poll
 to contribute to the conversation. I will use the responses to inform my articles in 
Harvard Business Review
, 
Fortune
, and 
Entrepreneur
.
Your Testimonials
You and others who gain value from Disaster Avoidance Experts 
services
 and thought leadership occasionally share testimonials about your experience, such as the one below. You can read more testimonials 
here
.
"I highly recommend Dr. Gleb coming to your Vistage meeting because it was an outstanding presentation. 
It was a presentation about really how you think, what kind of questions to ask, how to get through difficult situations.
 And the biggest thing we talk about at Vistage is decisions. After you leave this meeting, you're going to find out better ways of making decisions and the choices you make and the impact that it has on your business, your personal life, and your spiritual life."
-‌ 
Chet Tart
, Vistage Chair
Schedule a Free Consultation
 
What's Up With Me
It’s a puzzle to me why so many things that appear to be solely data-informed become so politicized.
 Why did WFH grow so politicized, for example? It’s not obvious at all that Republicans should favor government employees working in the office: after all, you can save a lot of money on real estate, as well as on hiring and retention costs, since people are willing to work for less and have better retention when they work remotely at least some of the time. Furthermore, productivity metrics and morale are higher when people can work remotely at least some of the time. But clearly, this issue did become politicized. Is it because of a lack of trust in public workers? Well, you can simply institute more clear accountability and tracking mechanisms, rather than forcing people back to the office, and losing all the benefits. It’s a clear example where culture wars win out over good, common business sense. 
Would love to get your feedback on what you found most useful about this edition of the “Wise Decision Maker Guide” - simply reply to this email.
Decisively Yours,
Dr. Gleb
Dr. Gleb Tsipursky
CEO of Disaster Avoidance Experts
PS: Are we connected on LinkedIn? If not, 
please add me
.
Did you miss out on reading any of my bestselling books?
Never Go With Your Gut: How Pioneering Leaders Make the Best Decisions and Avoid Business Disasters
 (Career Press, 2019)
The Blindspots Between Us: How to Overcome Unconscious Cognitive Bias and Build Better Relationships
 
(New Harbinger, 2020)
Returning to the Office and Leading Hybrid and Remote Teams: A Manual on Benchmarking to Best Practices for Competitive Advantage
 
(Intentional Insights, 2021)

forward this email

free

,

subject: Full Calendar - Upcoming Events
body:
From Day One is pleased to invite you to our upcoming events, each accredited by SHRM and HRCI, unless otherwise noted.
 
View this email in your browser
 
 
From Day One is pleased to invite you to our upcoming events
Our weekly 
webinars
 are each 60 minutes, complimentary to attend, and qualify for 1 credit from SHRM and HRCI.
Our monthly half-day 
virtual conferences 
include keynote, fireside chat, and panel discussions on our virtual main stage, as well as workshop sessions, chat, and one-on-one networking opportunities that facilitate interaction with our presenters and your fellow participants. They each qualify for 3 credits from SHRM and HRCI.
Our 
live events
 are coming to a city near you. Each one-day conference brings together leading thinkers and top executives in HR, talent acquisition, diversity, employee engagement, benefits, and CSR for an engaging, up-to-the-minute conversation about how employers can build stronger bonds of trust and connection with their workers and their communities. They each qualify for 4 credits from SHRM and HRCI.
Our 
half-day live events
 bring together leading thinkers and top executives in more focused sectors. They each qualify for 3 credits from SHRM and HRCI. 
LIVE EVENT - HALF DAY
 
April 2: Boston, MA - Benefits In 2025 And Beyond: Innovative And Inclusive Approaches For Worker Well-Being And Cost Effectiveness
A wide range of benefits allows employers to tackle a broad spectrum of their goals, spanning from retaining and engaging employees to promoting inclusion and belonging within the workplace. What are the cutting-edge benefits available that cater to the needs of every worker? How can companies evaluate their workforce needs and cultivate awareness and participation in their offerings? What trends are emerging and what can be expected in the future of benefits?
Register now
WEBINAR
 
April 8: The New Era of Workplace Giving: Meeting Donors Where They Are
Traditional workplace-giving programs often miss the mark. Employees want giving to feel personal, effortless, and seamlessly integrated into their daily lives. But how do companies meet these expectations while maintaining program efficiency and impact? Using Submittable’s digital “Impact Wallet,” companies are transforming their workplace-giving programs by shifting from one-size-fits-all models to hyper-personalized giving experiences. This innovative approach empowers employees to give when, where, and how they want—whether through direct donations, corporate rewards, payroll contributions, and more. Employees can create real-time impact via the fastest donation method in CSR.
What you'll learn: 
- How to transform workplace giving from transactional to meaningful and engaging
- Why flexibility and personalization are key to increasing donor participation
- How the Impact Wallet meets donors in their flow of life—whether through direct giving, rewards, payroll contributions, or the fastest donation method in CSR
- Real-world examples of companies enhancing their CSR impact and employee engagement
- Actionable steps to future-proof your giving programs and make generosity second nature
Register now
WEBINAR
 
April 15: The Personalized Benefits Playbook: How Smart Companies Can Win with LSAs
When it comes to benefits, employees want flexibility and choice, and admin teams need solutions that work. Lifestyle Spending Accounts (LSAs) are changing the game, and leading companies are using them to enhance well-being and support what matters most to employees – all while streamlining administration.
Join Forma for an exclusive conversation about how and why to launch LSAs, with real-world examples and benchmark data to back it up. From tackling traditional benefits challenges to designing a personalized benefits program that employees will love, you’ll get an upfront look at how smart companies can win with LSAs.
You'll learn:
- How LSAs work and why they’re growing in popularity across the world
- Traditional benefits challenges LSAs can solve
- Questions to ask to determine if LSAs are a fit for your company
- How to get started with LSAs
Register now
LIVE EVENT
 
April 16: Dallas, TX - The New Era of Investing in Humans
In the face of increasing pressure for productivity, how can companies grow while building a culture based on trust and values? Employers will need to take a greater stake in the future of their employees. In our conference of HR leaders and colleagues, we’ll explore breakthroughs in thinking about how to make work fulfilling, create a sense of community, help employees increase their skills and performance, and produce better managers. You’ll discover the most innovative approaches in such fields as talent acquisition, total rewards, benefits, learning and development, employee engagement, AI and HR technology, and inclusion and belonging.
Register now
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
April 23: Better Benefits: Supporting the Health and Well-Being of Workers and Their Families
When benefits leaders set high expectations for the quality and efficiency of the services they’re choosing for their company’s employees, the outcome can be a healthy workforce and a considerable return on investment. What innovative ways can benefits leaders stay in tune with what employees want, as well as evaluate the impact of those benefits? What are the latest developments in programs that offer support for women’s and family health, caregiving, mental health, and financial well-being?
Register now
LIVE EVENT - HALF DAY
 
April 23: New York, NY - Making Talent Acquisition a Strategic Part of Workforce Planning and Growth
At a time when many industries face talent shortages, TA leaders can play a pivotal role attracting and retaining hourly workers, finding unconventional pools of talent, taking part in succession planning, and embracing skills-based hiring to help meet future workforce needs. How can TA leaders improve their effectiveness and influence by modernizing their process, from the beginning of the pipeline to onboarding and advancement? What are the tools and new technology, including AI, that can help them?
Register now
LIVE EVENT - HALF DAY
 
April 24: New York, NY - Benefits In 2025 And Beyond: Innovative And Inclusive Approaches For Worker Well-Being And Cost Effectiveness
A wide range of benefits allows employers to tackle a broad spectrum of their goals, spanning from retaining and engaging employees to promoting inclusion and belonging within the workplace. What are the cutting-edge benefits available that cater to the needs of every worker? How can companies evaluate their workforce needs and cultivate awareness and participation in their offerings? What trends are emerging and what can be expected in the future of benefits?
Register now
WEBINAR
 
April 24: Measuring the Impact of Your Leadership Development Programs
Leadership development (LD) remains a top priority among CEOs in the midst of unprecedented transformations that require new and elevated skillsets for leaders. Yet the returns on LD investments are not always clear. MDA Leadership finds that organizations often sell LD programs short when they think solely in terms of the impact on the small cohort attending a given program. In fact, a well-designed program can have significant, measurable impact on a far larger number of people and result in more major business benefits than previously known. Join three experts to learn a powerful new way to develop and measure your LD programs to yield a greater return on investment.
Register now
WEBINAR
 
April 29: Breaking Barriers to Growth: Identifying What Holds Us Back
Whether at work or in our personal lives, unseen obstacles can prevent growth, innovation, and success. From ingrained habits and resistance to change to structural challenges and workplace culture, identifying what holds us back is the first step toward meaningful progress. Understanding these barriers not only fosters self-awareness but also empowers us to take actionable steps toward positive change. This webinar will explore common barriers—both individual and organizational—and provide practical strategies for overcoming them.
Register now
WEBINAR
 
May 6: Breaking the GLP-1 Cost Cycle for a Healthier Workforce, Lower Costs, and Smarter Care
GLP-1 medications are transforming the treatment of obesity, a challenge affecting millions of U.S. workers. Yet the high cost is a significant concern for companies looking to balance access with affordability. In this session, leaders from Noom will break down the GLP-1 cost cycle and identify ways organizations can provide affordable access to GLP-1s and other anti-obesity medications regardless of their coverage policies. You'll learn how the obesity crisis is affecting employers, the impact of GLP-1 compounds, and how Noom can help you confidently manage GLP-1 costs and achieve long-term return on investment.
Register now
LIVE EVENT
 
May 13: Minneapolis, MN - The New Era of Investing in Humans
In the face of increasing pressure for productivity, how can companies grow while building a culture based on trust and values? Employers will need to take a greater stake in the future of their employees. In our conference of HR leaders and colleagues, we’ll explore breakthroughs in thinking about how to make work fulfilling, create a sense of community, help employees increase their skills and performance, and produce better managers. You’ll discover the most innovative approaches in such fields as talent acquisition, total rewards, benefits, learning and development, employee engagement, AI and HR technology, and inclusion and belonging.
Register now
WEBINAR
 
May 15: The Real Impact of AI on Hiring: Staying Ahead of the Curve
Two years after ChatGPT reshaped the AI landscape, AI adoption has moved from hype to reality—seamlessly integrating into the tools we use daily. As hiring teams navigate this shift, understanding AI’s impact is more important than ever. In this fireside chat, Meredith Johnson, chief product officer at Greenhouse, will discuss how AI is already enhancing recruiting processes without adding complexity. You'll learn how AI is already embedded in your hiring workflow without extra steps, the real impact of AI-powered automation on recruiter efficiency, and what's next for AI in hiring—plus how to stay ahead of the curve.
Register now
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
May 21: The Role of HR Leaders in Building a Culture of Recognition and Feedback
Workers do better when they hear from managers and peers about how they’re doing. Yet many workers feel unappreciated or mystified about how their work is perceived. What are the organizational obstacles to providing better feedback? What are the most effective techniques for providing recognition? How can leaders get a better sense of a worker’s motivations, both intrinsic and extrinsic? What are the latest innovations in providing feedback in timely and impactful ways? How can managers be trained to be more conscious–and more fair-minded–about assigning non-promotable work, vs. status-granting tasks?
Register now
WEBINAR
 
May 22: Transforming Your Workforce With HR Tech: Boosting Engagement, Productivity, and Retention
Companies are leveraging HR technology to gain a competitive advantage over competitors while attracting and maintaining an engaged and productive workforce. From AI-driven benefits recommendations to flexible earned wage access, this session will explore how implementing the right innovative HR solutions can transform your business. From industry experts, you'll learn how innovation in HR technology can enhance employee engagement and productivity, how meaningful advances in technology can be leveraged as powerful tools for recruiting and retention, and which employee benefits have the greatest day-to-day impact.
Register now
WEBINAR
 
May 29: How AI Teammates are Transforming HR Operations
For too long, HR teams have been bogged down in administrative work, managing shared inboxes, responding to routine questions, and handling repetitive requests. But what if your HR team had an AI teammate that could handle the administrative burden, giving your people more time to focus on what really matters? In a fireside chat, Wisq CEO Jim Barnett sits down with a forward-thinking HR leader to explore how AI is already changing the game. You’ll hear firsthand how an organization can use purpose-built HR AI to improve productivity, enhance the employee experience, and free up time for more strategic, human-centered work.
Register now
WEBINAR
 
June 3: Building a Veteran-Ready Workforce: Empowering Your Military Hiring and Retention Strategy
Many companies support hiring military talent, but few have a structured approach to integrate and retain veterans, transitioning service members, and military spouses. Moving from military-friendly to veteran-ready requires intentional strategies, sustainable programs, and the right tools to bridge the gap between military experience and civilian careers. This session will provide employers with the knowledge and resources to develop military hiring programs that go beyond good intentions. We’ll cover best practices for leveraging government resources, creating veteran-friendly cultures, supporting military spouses, and using data-driven strategies to improve retention. Attendees will gain actionable insights into workforce trends, transition pipelines, apprenticeship programs, and National Guard and Reserve recruitment. Join us to evolve your hiring strategy and become truly veteran-ready, whether you're just starting or refining your military hiring efforts.
Register now
LIVE EVENT
 
June 5: Chicago, IL - The New Era of Investing in Humans
In the face of increasing pressure for productivity, how can companies grow while building a culture based on trust and values? Employers will need to take a greater stake in the future of their employees. In our conference of HR leaders and colleagues, we’ll explore breakthroughs in thinking about how to make work fulfilling, create a sense of community, help employees increase their skills and performance, and produce better managers. You’ll discover the most innovative approaches in such fields as talent acquisition, total rewards, benefits, learning and development, employee engagement, AI and HR technology, and inclusion and belonging.
Register now

June 10: New York, NY - The New Era of Investing in Humans

You’ll discover the most innovative approaches in such fields as talent acquisition, total rewards, benefits, learning and development, employee engagement, AI and HR technology, and inclusion and belonging.
Register now
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
June 11: Charting the Future of Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Belonging
Amid a backlash to the initiatives championed half a decade ago, employers are searching for direction on all the elements of DEI. For companies that have stayed the course on commitments made in 2020, has their rationale or articulation of their purpose changed, and how so? Has the business case for any aspect of DEI changed? How have some employers reframed their policy to focus more on inclusion and belonging, or expanded DEI roles to include supervision of talent management, corporate culture, and employee experience? What kind of anti-bias training programs are now deemed counter-productive, and which actually help? Are there alternative means for hiring and promoting the best candidates without considering demographics?
Register now
WEBINAR
 
June 12: Choosing a Financial Wellbeing Program That Produces Real Impact and Real Results
Explore what it takes to select and launch a successful financial well-being program—one that creates meaningful change in employees’ financial lives. In this session, you’ll hear best practices in program selection, implementation and launch, as well as real stories from employees whose lives were transformed through financial guidance. Gain insights into how leading companies are seeing lasting impact through thoughtful program design and rollout.
Register now
WEBINAR
 
June 17: The Untapped Power of Caregiving Benefits: Unlocking Productivity and Retention in the Workforce
Did you know that 73% of employees are juggling a hidden second job—caregiving? Whether it's caring for an aging parent, a child with special needs, or a spouse with a health condition, millions of employees are struggling to balance their professional and personal responsibilities. The result? Increased stress, decreased productivity, and higher turnover rates. Despite this growing challenge, many organizations overlook caregiving as a critical workforce issue. Traditional benefits and leave policies often fail to address the unique needs of working caregivers, leading to burnout, disengagement, and costly retention problems. Join this panel of leaders to explore innovative and actionable strategies for supporting employees while boosting productivity. Learn how enhancing benefits, flexibility, and workplace support can help you retain top talent.
Register now
WEBINAR
 
June 24: The HR Metrics That Matter: Defining ROI in a People-First Culture
Turn your HR data into a strategic advantage—no stats team required. In a world where every dollar counts and every initiative needs proof, HR leaders face rising pressure to show the real impact of investing in the productivity, retention, and well-being of their workers. But you don’t need to be a data scientist to demonstrate the value of your work. Join HiBob for a timely and practical conversation designed to help lean HR teams measure what matters—and tell a story that resonates with leadership.
Register now
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
July 16: Navigating the New Landscape of Employee-Benefit Solutions
What was once a fairly standard set of offerings has blossomed into myriad point solutions, many of them beneficial to workers yet creating a daunting task for benefits leaders to evaluate and adopt them. With such an abundance of choice, what  new approaches are benefits leaders taking to designing comprehensive benefits packages? How are benefits experts measuring employee expectations, quality of outcomes, and return on investment? How are they informing employees about the growing complexity of what’s available to them? How can employers hold vendors accountable for delivering on their promises–and carry out changes when needed? Where are areas in which data and AI can help with complicated decision-making?
Register now
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
August 13: Leading the Charge on Skills-Based Learning and Development
In the movement towards focusing more on skills than on degrees and work experience, L&D professionals are tasked with transforming age-old systems of measuring worker aptitude. What are the elements of moving toward a new system–and how can AI and other technologies help? What are the best methods of creating a taxonomy of skills needed in an organization, now and in the future? How can L&D leaders systematically judge situations where upskilling will be effective, or reskilling is needed? What are the best new methods of training, including the use of simulations to imitate real-world applications? Can employers design programs that have a more durable impact, so that workers don’t slip back into their old ways of doing things? How can L&D experts gain more insights from the skills data they’re gathering?
Register now
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
September 10: Productivity Boosters: How HR Leaders Can Play a Significant Role in Worker Efficiency
When workers can get more done with less time or effort, everyone benefits. How can HR leaders collaborate with their management peers to evaluate workflows, staffing levels, digital tools, and other elements that affect worker efficiency? What are the leadership approaches that increase workforce productivity–and how can managers be developed to lead with authenticity, empathy and adaptivity? Why do productivity-boosting changes often encounter resistance–and how can those obstacles be overcome? What is the role of priority-setting in helping workers manage their time?

In our conference of HR leaders and colleagues, we’ll explore breakthroughs in thinking about how to make work fulfilling, create a sense of community, help employees increase their skills and performance, and produce better managers. You’ll discover the most innovative approaches in such fields as talent acquisition, total rewards, benefits, learning and development, employee engagement, AI and HR technology, and inclusion and belonging.
Register now
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
October 15: Building and Managing a Global Workforce: Smart Strategies for Collaborating Across Borders
Most major corporations need to distribute their work across regions, markets, and labor pools. Yet it can be immensely challenging to overcome all the barriers of language, culture, legal systems, and the effect of time and distance. What solutions are talent-acquisition and talent-management experts using to close the gaps? What are the emerging technologies and leadership skills that can help managers be more effective in supervising both workflow and worker well-being? What are the keys to managing a contingent workforce on a globally coordinated basis?
Register now

October 21: Boston, MA - The New Era of Investing in Humans

You’ll discover the most innovative approaches in such fields as talent acquisition, total rewards, benefits, learning and development, employee engagement, AI and HR technology, and inclusion and belonging.
Register now
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
November 12: The Empowering Effect of HR Tech: Deciding Where It Will Make a Difference
A technology boom has provided HR leaders with both opportunities and challenges. On the one hand, AI and other new tech can help match people to workforce needs, reduce bias in hiring, and produce an abundance of data to inform people-management decisions. On the other hand, HR experts need to venture beyond their comfort zones to embrace new tech platforms, collaborate energetically with colleagues with different expertise, choose among myriad new offerings, and recognize the limits and pitfalls of technology. What ideas and advice can be offered by HR leaders who’ve taken an innovative approach to embracing new technology? What are the new frontiers yet to be explored?

December 10: What’s Around the Corner: Workers and Workplaces in 2026 and Beyond
Work changed radically in the first half of the decade, but more change is sure to come. What are the emerging contours? What further tasks will humans delegate to automation and what new skills will workers need to acquire? What will be the future of the full-time job, the career path, and the role of managers? HR leaders, researchers, thinkers and doers will offer their unconventional predictions about the future of work and workers.

subject: 🧠 Lack of Psychological Safety: Why Inclusion Can’t Survive Without It
body:
Continue reading to learn how to create a psychologically safe environment for all employees. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Larry!
 
🛑
 Picture this: 
You're leading a team meeting.
An employee has a brilliant idea, but they hesitate. 
"What if I am dismissed? What if I get labeled "difficult"?
So, they stay silent. Again. Now imagine this happening to employees across your organization, every single day. 
 
🤔
 The Experience: 
For many employees, especially those from underrepresented backgrounds, this is a daily reality.
They 
hold back
, they 
mask their identity
, they 
self-censor
, not because they don’t care…but because the environment has taught them it’s not safe to show up fully. 
Leaders like you are doing the work—you’re committed to DEI, you’ve launched initiatives, and built task forces. But without psychological safety, none of it sticks. 
 
⚠️
 The Problem: 
When your team doesn’t feel safe to speak up, challenge the status quo, or express themselves authentically, your organization suffers: 
Innovation stalls. 
Engagement declines. 
Diverse talent quietly leaves. 
Inclusion becomes performative. 
Lack of psychological safety 
erodes trust
, and with it, your DEI efforts lose their power. You’re left managing programs that check boxes but don’t change hearts.
 
💡
 The Future You’re Waiting For: 
Now, picture this instead: 
A culture where every employee—regardless of role, identity, or background—feels not just seen but 
safe
.
Where a Black employee challenges a policy without fear.
Where a trans team member can correct misgendering confidently.
Where junior staff raise bold ideas without worrying they’ll be shut down. 
That’s when DEI becomes more than a program—it becomes 
a lived experience
. 
And it starts with psychological safety. 
 
🎤
 What’s Next: 
In a few days, I’ll be sending you 
Part 2
, packed with specific, actionable strategies to build psychological safety in your workplace. 
Because inclusion can’t survive without it—and your people can’t thrive without it. 
👉
 Watch your inbox for the next email. It’s one you don’t want to miss. 
 
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, Founder and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.
At 
Mastering Cultural Differences LLC,
 we are committed to helping organizations build inclusive, culturally competent workplaces where every individual feels valued and respected. Through highly customized programs, we equip teams with knowledge and skills to help them connect and collaborate more effectively across differences.
